application many podcast apps will then regularly poll that RSS feed looking for updates typically it's about once an

update the RSS feed and then proactively download the media so that when you're
traveling if you're on the train and you lose network connectivity it doesn't drop out this is a great feature but it

front then gives you global distribution 101 pops I think hopefully that numbers still accurate changes quite regularly

your podcast so how do we optimize our delivery with cloud France well cloud fronts are caching service it
will case your content close to your listeners but we want to help cloud front do the best job possible so we
have two key files that listeners are going to be accessing we have the mp3 file the audio file that is larger you
know tens of megabytes typically and we have the RSS file it's very very small the mp3 file doesn't update often you
don't tend to overwrite an existing podcast but that RSS feed will update all the time so you want to have
different caching settings with cloud front and you can do this using the cache control header so this is an HTTP
header and if you set it to a large number cloud front will try to cut case your content for as long as possible
it's essentially a value in seconds this max-age value if you set it to a low number cloud front will periodically
refresh after that period to check your content when a user requests for it in the future so what you would typically
do is set large values for your mp3 file because it's not changing very often but
lower values something like 300 seconds for the RSS feed which allows you to update that feed and have your users get
the latest version of it quickly now by doing this you take a massive load off your origin server so this helps you
scale it helps you reach an audience without any disappointment of failed downloads or servers being overloaded
you can also control these settings within cloud 4 and itself with these maximum and minimum TTL settings that
you can see here at the bottom of the slide but I recommend you use it at the origin instead as I've shown above which
you can also set in s3 as object metadata the reason I suggest that is when you set in
front directly curved front we'll follow those headers but those headers will not be passed on to any downstream clients
so say you have listeners that are on a corporate network and everything goes through a proxy
well that proxy will respect the header at the top because it comes through with the requests in the lowercase cloud
fronts gonna respect it but the proxy downstream is not going to cache the content so next thinking about
understanding our audience you might want to track your audience you might want to understand who is actually requesting content so one thing you can
do is you can use things like query strings in your RSS feed to identify an individual user
but CloudFront will remove these by default when it forwards a request to your origin so you lose this information
and thus it doesn't show up in your your metrics or your reporting so if you whitelist a specific query strings a
user ID or a country code or something you embed within your RSS feed that will
come through to your origin it will reduce your case effectiveness but it the art is in choosing the right query
strings and only whitelisting those that you need to come through this will then mean that you can get much more detailed
reporting you can extract much more information from your origin server and understand your audience better and then
back to our problem of being successful the great problem to have well if your

front team are able to do reserve capacity pricing so if you have an unknown amount of traffic that you're

an origin request function as I mentioned it gets executed when there's a case miss but what's really

another thing that I discovered in in building out a proof-of-concept of this was when you have a query string come

strings on things that don't need to be there they miss things you end up with web server logs that actually have
different URIs and and different parameters depending on different applications and sometimes even different versions so you can use a tool
like elastic MapReduce or now even a device glue to clean up those logs to
get them into a normalized format that makes it really easy to report and ultimately you want to write that

to a platform like redshift which if you've got a lot of logs will make it really easy to report but you can also

so Athena lets you do ad hoc query on your data that's stored in s3 you don't need to run a an EMR cluster so you can
use Athena to query that data in its raw form perform some of the ETL s but you
can also use it to query your cleaned up data and get results really quickly and only pay for the queries that you're
actually executing you can plug Athena or finally you can plug Athena into quick site as well to get your reporting
visually done on a per query basis so analytics is something that you're
probably going to want to build and customize for your own usages as I've given you a few ideas about some
specific reports but Rob we were talking about when we were planning this podcast
asking you about the history of woosh go and and really you're saying that analytics was one of the key problems
you were looking to solve yeah absolutely it was when I got into this business but I used to run large radio
network in Australia and back in about 2012 I remember that podcasting started
to take off for us and our listeners wanted to consume the content on demand so we obviously were very interested in
